==European Championships== * Artistic Gymnastics: [[2007 Individual European Gymnastics Championships]] * Athletics: [[2007 European Indoor Championships in Athletics]] * Basketball: [[Eurobasket 2007]] * Figure Skating: [[2007 European Figure Skating Championships]] * Football (soccer): [[UEFA Champions League 2006-07]] * Football (soccer): [[UEFA Cup 2006-07]] * Football (soccer): [[2007 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]] * Football (soccer): [[UEFA Women's Cup 2006-07]] * Futsal: [[2007 UEFA Futsal Championship]] * Show jumping: [[2007 European Championships Show jumping]] * Volleyball: [[Men's CEV Champions League 2006-07]] * Volleyball: [[Women's CEV Champions League 2006-07]]
==Oceanian Championships== * Football (soccer): [[OFC Champions League 2007]] * Football (soccer): [[2007 OFC Women's Championship]]
==Pan American Championships / North American Championships== * Football (soccer): [[Caribbean Nations Cup 2007]] * Football (soccer): [[CONCACAF Champions' Cup 2007]] * Football (soccer): [[2007 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] * Multisport: [[2007 Pan American Games]]

{{Infobox sports season | title = 2016 Netball Superleague season | league = [[Netball Superleague]] | sport = [[Netball]] | logo = | pixels = | no_of_teams = 8 | attendance = | average_attendance = | TV = | season = 2016 Netball Superleague season | season_champs = [[Surrey Storm]] | season_champ_name= Champions | second_place= [[Manchester Thunder]] | minor_premiers= | MVP = | top_scorer = | seasonslist = | seasonslistnames = | prevseason_link = 2015 Netball Superleague season | prevseason_year = 2015 | nextseason_link = 2017 Netball Superleague season | nextseason_year = 2017 }} The '''2016 Netball Superleague season''' was the eleventh season of the [[Netball Superleague]], the elite domestic [[netball]] competition in the [[United Kingdom]]. ==Overview== ===Format=== The format was the same as the [[2015 Netball Superleague season|previous season]], with a double [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]] structure utilised. The top four teams qualify for the semi-finals, with the winners of these matches meeting in the Grand Final.{{cite web|url=https://www.scoreboard.com/en/netball/united-kingdom/superleague-2016/results/|title=2016 Superleague results|work=scoreboard.com}} ===Teams=== The following teams competed in the 2016 season:{{cite web|url=https://www.scoreboard.com/en/netball/united-kingdom/superleague-2016/|title=2016 Superleague overview|work=scoreboard.com}} {| class="wikitable" ! Team !! Base |- | [[File:CelticDragonsColours.png|20px|.]] '''[[Celtic Dragons]]''' || [[Cardiff]], Wales |- | [[File:YorkshireJetsColours.png|20px|.]] '''[[Yorkshire Jets]]''' || [[Yorkshire]], England |- | [[File:LoughboroughLightningColours.png|20px|.]] '''[[Loughborough Lightning]]''' || [[Loughborough]], Leicestershire |- | [[File:HertfordshireMavericksColours.png|20px|.]] '''[[Hertfordshire Mavericks]]''' || [[Hatfield, Hertfordshire|Hatfield]], Hertfordshire |- | [[File:ManchesterThunder.png|20px|.]] '''[[Manchester Thunder]]''' || [[Manchester]], Greater Manchester |- | [[File:SurreyStormColours.png|20px|.]] '''[[Surrey Storm]]''' || [[Guildford]], Surrey |- | [[File:TeamBathColours.png|20px|.]] '''[[Team Bath, Netball|Team Bath]]''' || [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], Somerset |- | [[File:TeamNorthumbriaColours.png|20px|.]] '''[[Team Northumbria]]''' || [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]], Tyne and Wear |} ==Results== ===Regular season=== * To read scores and statistics from all matches throughout the season [https://www.scoreboard.com/en/netball/united-kingdom/superleague-2016/results/ click here]. ===Ladder=== {{2016 Netball Superleague ladder}} ===Grand Final=== {{netballbox | bg = #EEEEEE | date = 8 May 2016 | time = 3.00pm | report = https://www.bbc.com/sport/netball/36238476 | stats = https://www.scoreboard.com/en/match/manchester-surrey-2016/vP6BlBR0/#match-summary | team1 = [[Manchester Thunder]] | score1 = 53 | team2 = [[Surrey Storm]] | score2 = 55 | Q1 = 9-15 | Q2 = 10-17 | Q3 = 17-11 | Q4 = 17-12 | H1 = | H2 = | ET = | goals1 = Cookey {{nb-goal|28|31}}

{{update|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox volleyball club |clubname = Aquacare Halen |short name = |nickname = |image = [[Image:Clublogoaquacarehalen.JPG|170px]] |fullname = |founded = |dissolved = |ground = De Koekoek
[[Halen]]
[[Belgium]] |capacity = |chairman = {{flagicon|Belgium}} Etienne de Séjournet de Rameignies |manager = |captain = |league = [[Liga Heren]] |season = |position = |pattern_la1= |pattern_b1= |pattern_ra1= |leftarm1=151B54 |body1=151B54 |rightarm1=151B54 |shorts1=151B54 |pattern_la3= |pattern_b3= |pattern_ra3= |leftarm3=FFFFFF |body3=FFFFFF |rightarm3=FFFFFF |shorts3=0000FF |website = http://aquacarehalen.newworld.be }} '''Volleybalclub Aquacare Halen''' is a [[volleyball]] club based in [[Halen]], [[Belgium]]. The men's A squad currently plays in the [[Liga Heren|Liga]], the highest level of Belgian men's volleyball. The club has been there since 2002. Their best league position was 5th, achieved in 2004-05, 2006-07 and 2007-08. Because of this, the team has already played three times in the [[Challenge Cup (volleyball)|Challenge Cup]], formerly known as CEV Cup. The club was founded in 2002 as a result of a merger between Schuvoc Herk-de-Stad en Halen VC. Those two teams also were the result of earlier mergers. The men's B and C squad, as well as the three women's teams, play in the lower, [[Limburg (Belgium)|provincial]] leagues. ==2010-11 squad== :[[Coach (sport)|Coach]]: {{flagicon|Sweden}} [[Johan Isacsson]] {| class="wikitable" ! # ! Nat. ! page.title: Australian cricket team in South Africa in 2017–18

revision.comment: /* 4th Test */ added space as per MoS
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox cricket tour | series_name = Australian cricket team in South Africa in 2017–18 | team1_image = Flag of South Africa.svg | team1_name = South Africa | team2_image = Flag of Australia.svg | team2_name = Australia | from_date = 22 February | to_date = 3 April 2018 | team1_captain = [[Faf du Plessis]] | team2_captain = [[Steve Smith (cricketer)|Steve Smith]]Suspended after day three of the Third Test.{{cite news|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/video/cameron-bancroft-ball-tampering-charge-yellow-tape-steve-smith-senior-players-australia-cape-town/2018-03-25|title=Bancroft charged, Smith admits ball tampering ploy|publisher=Cricket.com.au|access-date=25 March 2018}}
[[Tim Paine]]Captained Australia for day four of the Third Test, and for the Fourth Test.{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=12021470|title=Australian cricket ball tampering scandal: Steve Smith, David Warner and Cameron Bancroft only players involved, leave for Australia|date=27 March 2018|work=NZ Herald|access-date=27 March 2018|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777}} | no_of_tests = 4 | team1_tests_won = 3 | team2_tests_won = 1 | team1_tests_most_runs = [[Aiden Markram]] (480) | team2_tests_most_runs = [[Cameron Bancroft (cricketer)|Cameron Bancroft]] (223) | team1_tests_most_wickets = [[Kagiso Rabada]] (23) | team2_tests_most_wickets = [[Pat Cummins]] (22) | player_of_test_series = [[Kagiso Rabada]] (SA) }} The [[Australia national cricket team|Australia cricket team]] toured South Africa between February and April 2018 to play four [[Test cricket|Test]] matches.{{cite web |url=http://icc-live.s3.amazonaws.com/cms/media/about_docs/547c2a4d42a86-Copy%20of%20Copy%20of%20FTP%202015%20to%202019%20as%20at%20Nov%202014.pdf |title=Future Tours Programme |accessdate=16 January 2016 |work=International Cricket Council}}{{cite web |url=http://cricket.co.za/news/21171/CSA-announces-Zimbabwe-and-India-tour-itineraries |title=CSA announces Zimbabwe and India tour itineraries |accessdate=27 September 2017 |work=Cricket South Africa}} It was the first four-Test series between the two teams since South Africa's readmission.{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/story/1075520.html |title=Australia to tour SA for four Tests in 2018 |accessdate=4 January 2017 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}} Prior to the start of the tour, South African fast-bowler [[Morné Morkel]] announced that he would retire from international cricket at the end of the series.{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/story/1138001.html |title=Morkel to retire from international cricket after Australia series |accessdate=26 February 2018 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}} During the third Test, Morkel became the fifth bowler for South Africa to take 300 Test wickets.{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/22882784/morne-morkel-becomes-fifth-south-african-300-test-wickets |title=Morkel becomes fifth South African to 300 Test wickets |accessdate=23 March 2018 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}} During the third Test, Australian batsman [[Cameron Bancroft (cricketer)|Cameron Bancroft]] was charged with [[ball tampering]]. Captain [[Steve Smith (cricketer)|Steve Smith]] and Bancroft [[2018 Australian ball-tampering scandal|admitted the ball tampering]] to match referee [[Andy Pycroft]] and the media.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/cricket/43526870 |title=Cameron Bancroft: Australia player admits to ball-tampering, Steve Smith knew in advance |accessdate=24 March 2018 |work=BBC Sport}} Consequently, Smith and vice-captain [[David Warner (cricketer)|David Warner]] stood down from the team leadership, and [[wicket-keeper]] [[Tim Paine]] was appointed acting captain for the remainder of the match.{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/1141563.html |title=Steven Smith and Warner stood down as captain and vice-captain |accessdate=25 March 2018 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}} On 27 March 2018, Smith, Warner and Bancroft were all suspended by [[Cricket Australia]] and sent home, with Paine named as the captain for the fourth and final Test.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/steve-smith-cameron-bancroft-david-warner-charged-cricket-australia-tampering-renshaw-burns-maxwell/2018-03-28 |title=Trio suspended by Cricket Australia |accessdate=27 March 2018 |work=Cricket Australia}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/tim-paine-appointed-cricket-australia-46th-test-captain-board-steve-smith-sacked-tampering-scandal/2018-03-28 |title=Paine named Australia's 46th Test captain |accessdate=27 March 2018 |work=Cricket Australia}} The following day, Cricket Australia banned Smith and Warner for twelve months, with Bancroft receiving a nine-month ban.{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/1141869.html |title=Smith, Warner banned for 12 months by Cricket Australia |accessdate=28 March 2018 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/news/651272 |title=Smith, Warner given 12-month bans – official |accessdate=28 March 2018 |work=International Cricket Council}} After the three players had returned home, [[Darren Lehmann]], Australia's coach, announced that he would step down from his role after the conclusion of the fourth Test in [[Johannesburg]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/22952859/darren-lehmann-steps-australia-coach |title=Smith's tears force Lehmann to step down as Australia coach |accessdate=29 March 2018 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}} South Africa went on to win the Test series 3–1. It was the first time that South Africa had beaten Australia at home [[Australian cricket team in South Africa in 1969–70|since 1970]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/cricket/43625866 |title=South Africa beat Australia in fourth Test to win series 3-1 |accessdate=3 April 2018 |work=BBC Sport}} ==Squads== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; margin:auto" |- !colspan=2|Tests |- ! {{cr|SA}}{{cite news |title=Klaasen, Mulder in Test squad to face Australia |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/22560997/klaasen-mulder-sa-test-squad-face-australia |work=ESPN Cricinfo |date=24 February 2018 |accessdate=24 February 2018}} ! {{cr|AUS}}{{cite news |title=Jhye Richardson in for SA Tests, no room for Maxwell, [[Matt Renshaw]] * [[Jhye Richardson]] * [[Chadd Sayers]] * [[Mitchell Starc]] |} [[Jackson Bird]] was replaced in Australia's squad by [[Chadd Sayers]] before the tour began due to injury.{{cite news |title=Bird out, Sayers in for South Africa tour|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/jackson-bird-injury-hamstring-ruled-out-chadd-sayers-selected-australia-tour-south-africa-smith/2018-02-13|work=Cricket Australia|date=13 February 2018 |accessdate=13 February 2018}} South Africa's [[Kagiso Rabada]] was given a two-match ban by the [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) after he made contact with Australia's captain, [[Steve Smith (cricketer)|Steve Smith]], during the second Test, initially ruling him out of the rest of the series.{{cite news |title=Rabada handed two-Test suspension|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/1139998.html|work=ESPN Cricinfo|date=12 March 2018 |accessdate=12 March 2018}} On 20 March 2018, Rabada's two-match ban was overturned by the ICC, therefore allowing him to play in the rest of the series.{{cite news |title=Rabada not guilty of Level 2 offence but guilty of conduct contrary to the spirit of the game|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/media-releases/648345|work=International Cricket Council|date=20 March 2018 |accessdate=20 March 2018}} For the last two Tests of the series, [[Duanne Olivier]] and [[Chris Morris (cricketer)|Chris Morris]] were added to South Africa's squad.{{cite news |title=Olivier, Morris added to South Africa Test squad|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/22816897/duanne-olivier-chris-morris-added-south-africa-test-squad|work=ESPN Cricinfo|date=18 March 2018 |accessdate=18 March 2018}} Following the suspension of Steve Smith, David Warner and Cameron Bancroft after the third Test, [[Joe Burns (cricketer)|Joe Burns]], [[Glenn Maxwell]] and [[Matt Renshaw]] were added to Australia's squad for the fourth Test.{{cite news |title=Renshaw added to Australia's Test squad |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/1141805.html |work=ESPN Cricinfo |date=27 March 2018 |accessdate=27 March 2018}}{{cite news |title=Renshaw, Maxwell, Burns added to Australia squad for final Test |url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/news/650979 |work=International Cricket Council |date=27 March 2018 before bad light brings early end to day one |accessdate=1 March 2018 |work=Cricket World}} *''[[Aiden Markram]]'s (SA) score of 143 runs was the highest 4th innings score in a losing cause by an opener and also the highest by a South African batsman.{{Cite web|url=https://www.crictracker.com/south-africa-v-australia-2018-1st-test-day-5-statistical-highlights/|title=South Africa v Australia, 2018: 1st Test, Day 5 – Statistical Highlights |accessdate=1 March 2018 |work=CricTracker}} }} ===2nd Test=== {{Two-innings cricket match | date = 9–13 March 2018While five days of play were scheduled duties in the absence of Chris Gaffaney from day 2 onwards. {{cite web|url=https://wwos.nine.com.au/2018/03/10/19/13/sick-umpire-out-of-action-in-second-test |title=Sick umpire out of action in second Test |work=Nine News |accessdate=10 March 2018}} *''[[Shaun Marsh]] (Aus) scored his 2,000th run in Tests.{{cite web |url=http://www.sacricketmag.com/rabada-pus-sa-on-top/ |title=Rabada rips through Aussies |work=SA Cricket Mag |accessdate=9 March 2018}} }} ===3rd Test=== {{Two-innings cricket match | date = 22–26 March 2018 | team1 = {{cr-rt|SA}} | team2 = {{cr|AUS}} | score-team1-inns1 = 311 (97.5 overs) | runs-team1-inns1 = [[Dean Elgar]] 141[[not out|*]] (284) | wickets-team1-inns1 = [[Pat Cummins]] 4/78 (26 overs) | score-team2-inns1 = 255 (69.5 overs) | runs-team2-inns1 = [[Cameron Bancroft (cricketer)|Cameron Bancroft]] 77 (103) | wickets-team2-inns1 = [[Morné Morkel]] 4/87 (21 overs) | score-team1-inns2 = 373 (112.2 overs) | runs-team1-inns2 = [[Aiden Markram]] 84 (145) | wickets-team1-inns2 = [[Pat Cummins]] 3/67 (27 overs) | score-team2-inns2 = 107 (39.4 overs) | runs-team2-inns2 = [[David Warner (cricketer)|David Warner]] 32 (67) | wickets-team2-inns2 = [[Morné Morkel]] 5/23 (9.4 overs) | result = South Africa won by 322 runs | report = [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/1075984.html Scorecard] | venue = [[Newlands Cricket Ground]], [[Cape Town]] | umpires = [[Richard Illingworth]] (Eng) and [[Nigel Llong]] (Eng) | motm = [[Morné Morkel]] (SA) | toss = South Africa won the toss and elected to bat. | rain = | notes = [[Dean Elgar]] (SA) scored his 3,000th run in Tests.{{cite web |url=https://www.supersport.com/cricket/south-africa-v-australia-201718/news/180322/Solid_Elgar_Amla_reach_lunch |title=Elgar edges closer to century |work=SuperSport |accessdate=22 March 2018}} Elgar also became the first player to [[Carry the bat|carry his bat]] twice in the same year, and the [[List of cricketers who have carried the bat in international cricket|second batsman to carry his bat three times]] in Tests.{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/22881904/dean-elgar-joins-desmond-haynes-carrying-bat-honours-board |title=Elgar joins Haynes in carrying-the-bat honours board |work=ESPN Cricinfo |accessdate=23 March 2018}} *''[[Steve Smith (cricketer)|Steve Smith]] (Aus) equalled the joint record of taking five catches as a non-wicket-keeper in a Test innings, becoming the eleventh fielder to achieve this.{{cite web|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/steve-smith-slips-catches-test-record-equalled-south-africa-australia-third-test-highlights-day-two/2018-03-23|title=Steve Smith joins elite club for taking 5 test catches in a single test innings|work=CricketAustralia|access-date=23 March 2018}} *''[[Morné Morkel]] became the fifth bowler for South Africa to take [[List of South Africa Test cricket records#Most career wickets|300 wickets in Tests]].{{cite web |url=https://www.sport24.co.za/Cricket/Proteas/morkel-joins-300-club-at-newlands-20180323 |title=Morkel joins '300 club' at Newlands |work=Sport24 |accessdate=23 March 2018}} *''[[Tim Paine]] replaced Steve Smith as [[List of Australia national cricket captains#Test captains|captain of Australia]] on day four.{{cite web |url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/news/650526 |title=Smith, Warner stand down as captain and vice-captain |work=International Cricket Council |accessdate=25 March 2018}} *''[[Nathan Lyon]] became the sixth bowler for Australia to take [[List of Australia Test cricket records#Most career wickets|300 wickets in Tests]].{{cite web |url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/nathan-lyon-300-test-wickets-australia-south-africa-cape-town/2018-03-25 |title=Lyon joins elite with 300th Test scalp |work=Cricket Australia |accessdate=25 March 2018}} }} ====Ball tampering==== {{main|2018 Australian ball-tampering scandal}} On the third day of the third Test, Australia's [[Cameron Bancroft (cricketer)|Cameron Bancroft]] was shown on television coverage, also shown live at the ground, to have [[Ball tampering|tampered with the ball]] with a small, yellow object. Bancroft later revealed the object to be a short length of yellow adhesive tape to which dirt and grit had adhered, forming an abrasive surface,{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/22896372/cameron-bancroft-centre-alleged-ball-tampering-row |title=Cameron Bancroft at centre of alleged ball-tampering row |accessdate=24 March 2018 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/news/650423 |title=Bancroft and Smith answer to ball tampering allegations |accessdate=24 March 2018 |work=International Cricket Council}} though four days later, Cricket Australia confirmed that the object was actually [[sandpaper]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/sandpaper-not-sticky-tape-revelation-australia-media-statement-ball-tampering-cameron-bancroft/2018-03-28|title=Sticky truth about sandpaper revelation|work=cricket.com.au|access-date=28 March 2018|language=en}} At the end of the day's play, both Bancroft and captain [[Steve Smith (cricketer)|Steve Smith]] admitted to ball tampering, with Smith knowing of the plan in advance of Bancroft's actions.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/cameron-bancroft-steve-smith-ball-tampering-umpires-tape-pockets-australia-cape-town-video/2018-03-25 |title=Australia own up to ball tampering |accessdate=24 March 2018 |work=Cricket Australia}} [[Andy Pycroft]], the [[match referee]], charged Bancroft with a Level 2 offence of attempting to alter the condition of the ball. Smith said it was a "big mistake" but stated he would not be standing down.{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/22897995/desperation-drove-australia-cheat-steven-smith |title=Desperation drove Australia to cheat - Smith |accessdate=24 March 2018 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}} Smith and vice-captain [[David Warner (cricketer)|David Warner]] subsequently stood aside from leadership roles for the remainder of the Test, with [[Tim Paine]] taking over as acting captain.{{cite web|last1=Matthey|first1=James|author2=Blair, Alex|title=SMITH STANDS DOWN: Australia has a new Test captain|url=http://www.news.com.au/sport/cricket/live-australia-vs-south-africa-day-four-of-the-third-test-in-cape-town/news-story/3436c4f388d143afefebd0ec44ee2872|website=news.com.au|accessdate=25 March 2018}} The [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) suspended Smith for one match, handed him four demerit points and fined him 100% of his match fee.{{Cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/media-releases/650624 |title=Steve Smith suspended and Bancroft handed three demerit points |accessdate=25 March 2018 |work=International Cricket Council}} Cameron Bancroft was handed three demerit points and fined 75% of his match fee. On 27 March 2018, Cricket Australia CEO [[James Sutherland (cricket administrator)|James Sutherland]] announced that as a result of the preliminary investigation Smith, Warner and Bancroft had been charged with bringing the game into disrepute, suspended and sent home. [[Matt Renshaw]], [[Joe Burns (cricketer)|Joe Burns]] and [[Glenn Maxwell]] were recalled to the squad for the fourth Test to replace them. On 28 March, Cricket Australia released their findings and the sanctions to be imposed. Smith and Bancroft respectively received 12 and 9 month bans from international and domestic cricket in Australia, and neither would be considered for a leadership role for a further 12 months after that ban finishes. Warner received an identical 12 month ban, and would never be considered again for a leadership position. All three were encouraged to return to club level cricket to reconnect with the general cricket community.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/player-sanctions-steve-smith-cameron-bancroft-david-warner-australia-cricket-ball-tampering/2018-03-28 |title=Tampering trio learn their fate |accessdate=28 March 2018 |work=Cricket Australia}} ===4th Test=== {{Two-innings cricket match | date = 30 March – 3 April 2018 | team1 = {{cr-rt|SA}} | team2 = {{cr|AUS}} | score-team1-inns1 = 488 (136.5 overs) | runs-team1-inns1 = [[Aiden Markram]] 152 (216) | wickets-team1-inns1 = [[Pat Cummins]] 5/83 (28.5 overs) | score-team2-inns1 = 221 (70 overs) | runs-team2-inns1 = [[Tim Paine]] 62 (161) | wickets-team2-inns1 = [[Vernon Philander]] 3/30 (18 overs) | score-team1-inns2 = 344/6[[Declaration and forfeiture#Declaration|d]] (105 overs) | runs-team1-inns2 = [[Faf du Plessis]] 120 (178) | wickets-team1-inns2 = [[Pat Cummins]] 4/58 (18 overs) | score-team2-inns2 = 119 (46.4 overs) | runs-team2-inns2 = [[Joe Burns (cricketer)|Joe Burns]] 42 (80) | wickets-team2-inns2 = [[Vernon Philander]] 6/21 (13 overs) | result = South Africa won by 492 runs | report = [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/1075985.html Scorecard] | venue = [[Wanderers Stadium]], [[Johannesburg]] | umpires = [[Ian Gould]] (Eng) and [[Nigel Llong]] (Eng) | motm = [[Vernon Philander]] (SA) | toss = South Africa won the toss and elected to bat. | rain = | notes = [[Tim Paine]] became the [[List of Australia national cricket captains#Test captains|46th captain of Australia in Tests]], following Steve Smith's suspension. *''[[Chadd Sayers]] (Aus) made his Test debut. *''[[Vernon Philander]] (SA) took his 200th wicket in Tests.{{cite web|url=https://www.sport24.co.za/Cricket/Proteas/philander-joins-200-club-at-wanderers-20180403 |title=Philander joins '200 club' at Wanderers |work=Sport24 |accessdate=3 April 2018}} *''South Africa's victory was the biggest margin in Tests, in terms of runs, since Australia beat England by 562 runs in [[Australian cricket team in England in 1934#Fifth Test|August 1934]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/23012008/biggest-test-win-1934 |title=Biggest Test win since 1934 |work=ESPN Cricinfo |accessdate=3 April 2018}} *''This was Australia's [[List of Australia Test cricket records#Greatest loss margins (by runs)|second largest]] defeat by number of runs in Tests.{{cite web|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/match-report/day-five-south-africa-australia-fourth-test-watch-live-video-highlights-ball-tampering-scores/2018-04-04 |title=Australia slump to 90-year low |work=Cricket Australia |accessdate=3 April 2018}} *''This was [[Morne Morkel]]'s last international match. }} ==Notes== {{reflist|group="n"}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Infobox football tournament | name = Super Cup | current = [[2013 Grameenphone Super Cup]] | logo = GP Bangladesh Super Cup Logo.jpg | founded = {{Start date and age|2009}} | number of teams = 8 | region = Bangladesh | current champions = [[Mohammedan Sporting Club (Dhaka)|Mohammedan SC]]
(2nd title) | most successful club = [[Mohammedan Sporting Club (Dhaka)|Mohammedan SC]]
(2 titles) | broadcasters = [[Bangladesh Television]] | website = {{URL|bffonline.com}} }} '''Super Cup''' is the highest-budgeted football competition organized by the [[Bangladesh Football Federation]] and is one of the two club football season cups in Bangladesh, the other being [[Federation Cup (Bangladesh)|Federation Cup]]. It started in 2009 . The tournament is currently sponsored by [[Grameenphone]]. == History == The competition kicked off for the first time on Wednesday, 11 March 2009 inaugurated by [[Citycell]]'s Chief Executive Officer Michel Seamour and the Federation's president [[Kazi Salahuddin]]{{ cite web|title=Citycell Super Cup Football Flying start for Abahani |work=The New Nation |url=http://www.ittefaq.com/issues/2009/03/12/news0893.htm |doi= |accessdate=2010-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713070527/http://www.ittefaq.com/issues/2009/03/12/news0893.htm |archivedate=13 July 2011 }} in which [[Mohammedan Sporting Club (Dhaka)|Mohammedan Sporting Club]] became the first champion beating arch-rival [[Abahani Limited Dhaka|Abahani Limited]]. The prize money for the tournament was $ 150,000 which is said to be a record in Asia. Mohammedan defeated the country's [[Bangladesh Premier League (football)|Premier League]] winners Abahani 1-0 in an exciting final attended by a crowd of 40,000 in the country's main international football venue [[Bangabandhu National Stadium]].{{ cite web| title =Bangladesh: Mohammedan SC Clinch CityCell Super Cup | work =goal.com| url =http://www.goal.com/en/news/14/asia/2009/03/27/1177942/bangladesh-mohammedan-sc-clinch-citycell-super-cup| doi=| accessdate =2010-08-14}} The second Super Cup was on 6 August 2011 at Bangabandhu National Stadium by 2010-2011 season champion Abahani Ltd beating Mohammedan SC in a heated remeet.http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=197084 The third Super Cup was held in June 2013 in which [[Mohammedan Sporting Club (Dhaka)|Mohammedan Sporting Club]] became champion for the second time by beating [[2012–13 Bangladesh Football Premier League]] champion [[Sheikh Russel KC]].{{ cite web |url=http://demo.bdwebtech.com/bff/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1709&Itemid=195 |title=Grameenphone Super Cup 2013 |work=[[Bangladesh Football Federation]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130809081447/http://demo.bdwebtech.com/bff/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1709&Itemid=195 |archive-date=2013-08-09 |accessdate=2013-07-06}} ==Winners== * 2009 : [[Mohammedan Sporting Club (Dhaka)|Mohammedan Sporting Club]] * 2011 : [[Abahani Limited Dhaka|Abahani Limited]] * 2013 : [[Mohammedan Sporting Club (Dhaka)|Mohammedan Sporting Club]] ==Statistics by club== {| class="wikitable" |- !Team !Winner !Runners-up !Years won !Years runners-up |- | [[Mohammedan Sporting Club (Dhaka)|Mohammedan Sporting Club]]||align=center|2||align=center|1||2009, 2013||2011 |- | [[Abahani Limited Dhaka|Abahani Limited]]||align=center|1||align=center|1||2011||2009 |- | [[Sheikh Russel KC]]||align=center|0||align=center|1||||2013 |} ==Sponsorship== * 2009 : [[Citycell]] * 2011 & 2013 : [[Grameenphone]] ==See also== * [[Dhaka Derby]] * [[Football in Bangladesh]] * [[List of Bangladeshi football champions]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} {{Football in Bangladesh}} {{National football Supercups (AFC region)}} [[Category:Football cup [[Albert Russell (director)|Albert Russell]] | starring = [[Gloria Swanson]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = [[Universal Pictures]] | released = {{film date|1917|5|8}} | runtime = 3 reels | country = United States | language = [[Silent film|Silent]]
English intertitles | budget = }} '''''Baseball Madness''''' is a 1917 American [[silent film|silent]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Billy Mason (actor)|Billy Mason]] and starring [[Gloria Swanson]].{{cite web |url=http://www.silentera.com/PSFL/data/B/BaseballMadness1917.html |title=Progressive Silent Film List: Baseball Madness |accessdate=2009-07-04|work=Silent Era}} ==Cast== * [[Gloria Swanson]] * [[Billy Mason (actor)|Billy Mason]] * [[Orin Jackson]] (as Orin C. Jackson) * [[Mark Fenton]] * [[Countess Du Cello]] (as Countess Mary Du Cello) * [[Victor Potel]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Imdb title|id=0326751|title=Baseball Madness}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baseball Madness}} [[Category:1917 films]] [[Category:1910s comedy films]] [[Category:1910s short films]] [[Category:1910s sports films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:American comedy films]] [[Category:American silent short films]] [[Category:American sports comedy films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Universal Pictures films]] [[Category:Comedy short films]] {{1910s-short-comedy-film-stub}}

A '''bowl-out''' (sometimes termed a '''bowl-off''') is used in various forms of [[limited overs cricket]] to decide a match that would otherwise end in a [[result (cricket)#Tie|tie]]. The procedure is similar to a [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalty shootout]] in [[association football|football]]. Five bowlers from each side deliver one or two balls each at an unguarded [[wicket]] (three [[stump (cricket)#Part of the wicket|stumps]]).<ref>Mott, Oliver [http://static.ecb.co.uk/files/cct20-rules-2009-final-10524.pdf CCT20 Rules 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928113842/http://static.ecb.co.uk/files/cct20-rules-2009-final-10524.pdf |date=2011-09-28 }}, 7 May 2009, [[England and Wales Cricket Board|ECB]]. Retrieved on 31 July 2009.</ref> If each team has hit the same number of wickets after the first five bowlers per side, the bowling continues and is decided by [[sudden death (sport)|sudden death]].
==History== ===First match decided by bowl-out=== A bowl-out was first used in the [[NatWest Trophy]] in June 1991 in a match between Derbyshire and Minor County side Hertfordshire at Bishops Stortford. Derbyshire bowled first and Steve Goldsmith managed one hit from his two deliveries. Ole Mortensen, Alan Warner, Frank Griffiths and Simon Base all missed with both of theirs. Hertfordshire's first bowler, Andy Needham, hit with his first ball but missed with his second. John Carr missed with both of his, but Bill Merry struck middle with his second attempt to win the match.{{citation needed|date=November 2009}}
===International Cricket=== The [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) introduced the bowl-out should scores be tied in the semifinals and final of the [[2006 ICC Champions Trophy]] or the [[2007 Cricket World Cup]], although it was not required to be used in either tournament. At the ICC Annual Conference 2008 it was decided that the bowl-out should be replaced by a one-over "eliminator" (also called a "[[Super Over]]") in the [[2009 ICC Champions Trophy|2008 ICC Champions Trophy]] (postponed to 2009) and the [[2009 ICC World Twenty20]].
==Twenty20== ===International T20=== Up until the introduction of the "[[Super Over]]" in [[Twenty20 International|International Twenty20]] cricket, if a match ended with the scores level (either because both teams reached the same score after 20 [[over (cricket)|overs]], or the second team scored exactly the par score under the [[Duckworth-Lewis method]]), the tie was broken with a bowl-out. The first international bowl-out in a Twenty20 match took place on 16 February 2006, when [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] beat [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] 3-0 in [[Auckland]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/4715558.stm Kiwis defeat Windies in bowl out] ([[BBC News]], 16 February 2005)</ref><ref>[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=6&click_id=17&art_id=qw1140085801198S163 Black Caps win first-ever bowl-off] ([[Independent Online]], 16 February 2005)</ref> A bowl-out was also used on 14 September 2007 when [[India national cricket team|India]] beat [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] 3-0 during the [[2007 ICC World Twenty20]] in [[Durban]], [[South Africa]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/cricket/6993851.stm India defeat Pakistan in bowl-out] ([[BBC News]], 14 September 2007)</ref>
===Domestic T20=== A bowl-out was first used to decide a domestic Twenty20 match when Surrey beat Warwickshire in July 2005.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/counties/4693841.stm Surrey beat Bears after bowl-out] ([[BBC News]], 18 July 2005)</ref> ==Current use== In some forms of domestic one-day cricket competition, a bowl-out is used to decide the result when the match is tied or rained out: for example, the quarterfinal of the [[MCCA Knockout Trophy|Minor Counties Cricket Association Knockout Trophy]] in 2004, when [[Northumberland County Cricket Club|Northumberland]] beat [[Cambridgeshire County Cricket Club|Cambridgeshire]] 4-2.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?view=DETAILS&grid=&xml=/sport/2004/07/09/scmino09.xml Holders feel blue after bowl-out] (''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', 9 July 2004)</ref> In the [[2009 Twenty20 Cup]], [[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]] beat [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] 5-1 to reach the semi-final stage.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/counties/8176034.stm Somerset beat Lancs in bowl-out], 30 July 2009, [[BBC Sport]]. Retrieved on 31 July 2009.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox rugby team | country = Cameroon | image = Cameroon Rugby Union.gif | imagesize = 100px | union = Fédération Camerounaise de Rugby | nickname = Indomitable Lions | coach = [[Philippe Saint-André]] | capitan = | from = | caps = | top scorer = | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | leftarm1 = | body1 = | rightarm1 = | shorts1 = | socks1 = | first = {{ru|Cameroon}} 24-25 {{ru|Zambia}}
(28 July 2001) | bigwin = {{ru|Cameroon}} 81-0 {{ru|Mauritania}}
(10 October 2003) | bigloss = {{ru|Kenya}} 76-8 {{ru|Cameroon}}
(13 July 2008) | no World cup apps = 0 | year = | url = }} The '''Cameroon national rugby union team''' represent [[Cameroon]] in the sport of [[rugby union]]. They are ranked as a tier-three nation by the [[International Rugby Board]] (IRB). Cameroon have thus far not qualified for a [[Rugby World Cup]], but have competed in qualifying tournaments. Cameroon also compete annually in the [[Africa Cup]]. ==History== In 2001 Cameroon played in the [[2003 Rugby World Cup - Africa qualification|African qualification tournaments]] for the [[2003 Rugby World Cup]] in Australia. Grouped in Pool A of Round 1, along with [[Uganda national rugby union team|Uganda]] and [[Zambia national rugby union team|Zambia]]. Cameroon lost their first match by one point, 25-24 to Zambia, but then defeated Uganda 17 to nil. Cameroon finished first in the final standings, advancing to Round 2. In Round 2 Cameroon faced both [[Kenya national rugby union team|Kenya]] and [[Madagascar national rugby union team|Madagascar]]. In their first match, Cameroon lost to Madagascar. They finished third in the standings after then losing to Kenya. Cameroon participated in the [[2007 Rugby World Cup - Africa qualification|African qualifying tournament]] for the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]], playing in the Northern Pool of Round 1a, along with [[Senegal national rugby union team|Senegal]] and [[Nigeria national rugby union team|Nigeria]]. Cameroon finished second in the final standings after narrowly losing to Senegal, and defeating Nigeria. They also competed in the [[2006 Africa Cup]]. ==World Cup record== * 1987 - No qualifying tournament held * 1991 - 1999 - Did not enter * 2003 - 2011 - Did not qualify * 2015 - Withdrew ==Results summary== As of 11 December 2012 their record against all nations is as follows:{{cite web |url= http://www.rugbydata.com/cameroon|title= International Rugby Union Statistics: Cameroon |author= |date= |work= |publisher= Rugbydata.com |accessdate=8 July 2011}} {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! {{Infobox rugby league football competition | name = Cumbria Shield | logo = | sport = Rugby Union | founded = {{Start date and age|1888}} (Cumberland Challenge Shield)
{{Start date and age|1974}} (Cumbria Shield) | folded = | country = {{ENG}} | teams = | champion = [[Wigton RUFC|Wigton II]] (10th title) | season = 2017-18 | most_champs = [[Workington RFC|Workington]] | count = 18 | website = [http://cumbriarfu.pitchero.com/ Cumbria Rugby Union] }} The '''Cumbria Shield''' is an annual [[rugby union]] knock-out club competition organized by the [[Cumbria Rugby Union]]. It was introduced during the 1888-89 season, when it was known as the Cumberland Challenge Shield, and the inaugural winners were [[Millom RUFC|Millom]]. Initially it was open only to junior club sides in [[Cumberland]] (senior sides played in the [[Cumbria Cup|Challenge Cup]]) but in 1974, as a result of the [[1972 Local Government Act]], Cumberland, [[Westmorland]] and [[Furness]] merged to form what we now know as [[Cumbria]], and the competition would ultimately be renamed as the Cumbria Shield.{{cite web|url=http://www.angelfire.com/sports/cumbriarl/history.html|title=History|publisher=Angelfire|accessdate=10 July 2017 }} It is the third most important cup competition in Cumbria, behind the [[Cumbria Cup]] and [[Cumbria League Cup]]. Originally the Shield was a knock-out cup played by the 1st teams of junior clubs, along with the 2nd teams of senior clubs, before becoming mostly a 2nd team competition.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsandstar.co.uk/sport/rugby-union/article/Cumbria-Shield-second-team-tournament-set-for-revival-af744bfd-5728-4552-a551-d9390f44dd2e-ds|title=Cumbria Shield second team tournament set for revival|publisher=News & Star|date=29 May 2004 }} In later years the format switched back and forth between a knock-out cup and league cup-hybrid, but has most recently switched to being awarded to the winners of the Cumbria Shield League - a regional league for 2nd and 3rd teams in Cumbria. A secondary competition known as the Cumbria Vase was introduced in 2007 initially for sides knocked out of the early rounds of the Shield competition, although in recent years it seems to have become a stand-alone cup competition for 2nd teams in the region. ==Cumbria Shield winners== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" |- |colspan="5" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"| {| border="0" {{col-begin|width=100%}} {{col-1-of-2}} ===Shield=== *[[Workington RFC|Workington II]] (19){{#tag:ref|Workington have won 19 Challenge Shield titles including the 1909 win by Workington Trades RUFC - the side that would merge with Workington RUFC in 1910 to form the current club. Figure also includes titles won by the 1st XV.{{cite web|url=http://www.pitchero.com/clubs/workington/a/history-8270.html|title=History |publisher=Workington RFC (Pitchero)|accessdate=10 July 2017 }}|group=a}} *[[Aspatria RUFC|Aspatria II]] (16) *[[Wigton RUFC|Wigton II]] (10) *[[Netherhall RUFC|Netherhall II]] (9){{#tag:ref|Includes 8 titles won by Netherhall Old Boys.|group=a}} *[[St Benedict's RUFC|St Benedict's]] (9){{#tag:ref|Includes both 1st and 2nd team titles.|group=a}} *[[Millom RUFC|Millom]] (6) *[[Silloth RUFC|Silloth]] (6) *[[Cockermouth RUFC|Cockermouth II]] (5) *[[Egremont RUFC|Egremont II]] (5) *[[Penrith RUFC|Penrith]] (5){{#tag:ref|Includes titles won by both the 2nd and 3rd teams.|group=a}} *[[Whitehaven RUFC|Whitehaven II]] (4) *[[Moresby RUFC|Moresby]] (3) *[[Blennerhasset RUFC|Blennerhasset II]] (1) *[[Border Regiment RUFC|Border Regiment]] (1) *[[Carlisle RFC|Carlisle 'A']] (1) *[[Clifton RUFC (Cumbria)|Clifton]] (1){{#tag:ref|No relation to the better known [[Clifton Rugby Football Club|Clifton RFC]] who are based in [[Bristol]].|group=a}} *[[Cumberland and Westmorland Police RUFC|Cumberland & Westmorland Police]] (1) *[[High Moor Rovers Dearham]] (1) *[[Kendal Rugby Union Football Club|Kendal II]] (1) *[[Kirkby Lonsdale RUFC|Kirkby Lonsdale II]] (1) *[[Maryport RLFC|Maryport II]] (1){{#tag:ref|Maryport were Challenge Shield winners during the 1890s before they switched over to [[Rugby league|Rugby League]] in 1898-99.{{cite web|url=http://www.pitchero.com/clubs/maryportarlfc/a/history-7494.html?page=3|title=History 3|publisher=Maryport ARLFC (Pitchero)|accessdate=10 July 2017 }}|group=a}} *[[United Steels S.O RUFC|United Steels S.O]] (1) *[[Wath Brow RUFC|Wath Brow]] (1) *[[Whitehaven Recreation RLFC|Whitehaven Recreation]] (1){{#tag:ref|Whitehaven Recreation won a Challenge Shield during the 1890s before switching to [[Rugby League]] in 1898. Despite being based in the same town they do not seem to have any connection with [[Whitehaven R.L.F.C.]], who were formed much later in 1948.{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehavenrl.co.uk/history|title=Foundation|publisher=Whitehaven Rugby League Football Club|accessdate=10 July 2017 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.totalrl.com/forums/index.php?/topic/282711-calling-rl-historians/|title=Calling RL historians|publisher=Total Rugby League Fans Forum|date=8 March 2016}}|group=a}} *[[Wigton Hornets]] (1){{#tag:ref|It is not clear if Wigton Hornets were in any way related to Wigton RUFC - they could possibly have been the name for the Wigton 2nd team or even a separate club.|group=a}} *[[Workington RFC|Workington Trades]] (1) {{col-2-of-2}} === Vase === *[[Kendal Rugby Union Football Club|Kendal 'A']] (3) *[[Carlisle RFC|Carlisle 'A']] (2) *[[Creighton RFC|Creighton]] (1) *[[Penrith RUFC|Penrith III]] (1) {{col-end}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=a}} ==See also== * [[Cumbria Rugby Union]] * [[Cumbria Cup]] * [[Cumbria League Cup]] * [[Westmorland and Furness Cup|Westmorland & Furness Cup]] ==References== {{reflist|40em}} ==External links== * [http://cumbriarfu.pitchero.com/ Cumbria RU] {{Rugby union in England}} [[Category:Recurring sporting events established in 1888]] [[Category:1888 establishments in England]] [[Category:Rugby union cup competitions in England]] [[Category:Rugby union in Cumbria]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Glycogenesis|Glyceroneogenesis}} [[File:Gluconeogenesis.png|thumb|Simplified Gluconeogenesis Pathway]] '''Gluconeogenesis''' ('''GNG''') is a [[metabolic pathway]] that results in the generation of [[glucose]] from certain non-[[carbohydrate]] carbon substrates. From breakdown of [[protein]]s, these substrates include [[glucogenic amino acid]]s (although not [[ketogenic amino acid]]s); from breakdown of [[lipid]]s (such as [[triglyceride]]s), they include [[glycerol]], odd-chain fatty acids (although not even-chain fatty acids, see below); and from other steps in [[metabolism]] they include [[pyruvic acid|pyruvate]] and [[lactic acid|lactate]].
Gluconeogenesis is one of several main mechanisms used by humans and many other animals to maintain [[blood sugar|blood glucose levels]], avoiding low levels ([[hypoglycemia]]). Other means include the degradation of [[glycogen]] ([[glycogenolysis]])<ref>{{cite web |last=Silva |first=Pedro |title=The Chemical Logic Behind Gluconeogenesis |url=http://www2.ufp.pt/~pedros/bq/gng.htm |accessdate=September 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826043311/http://www2.ufp.pt/~pedros/bq/gng.htm |archivedate=August 26, 2009 |df= }}</ref> and [[fatty acid metabolism#Fatty acid catabolism|fatty acid catabolism]].
Gluconeogenesis is a ubiquitous process, present in plants, animals, fungi, bacteria, and other microorganisms.<ref>{{cite book |title=Lehninger Principles of Biochemistry |year=2000 |publisher=Worth Publishers |location=USA |isbn=1-57259-153-6 |page=724 |author1=David L Nelson |author2=Michael M Cox }}</ref> In vertebrates, gluconeogenesis takes place mainly in the [[liver]] and, to a lesser extent, in the [[renal cortex|cortex]] of the [[kidney]]s. In [[ruminants]], this tends to be a continuous process.<ref name="pmid320235">{{cite journal | author = Young JW | title = Gluconeogenesis in cattle: significance and methodology | journal = J. Dairy Sci. | volume = 60 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–15 | year = 1977 | pmid = 320235 | doi = 10.3168/jds.S0022-0302(77)83821-6 }}</ref> In many other animals, the process occurs during periods of [[fasting]], [[starvation]], [[low-carbohydrate diet]]s, or intense [[exercise]]. The process is highly [[endergonic]] until it is coupled to the hydrolysis of [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] or [[Guanosine triphosphate|GTP]], effectively making the process [[exergonic]]. For example, the pathway leading from [[pyruvate]] to [[glucose-6-phosphate]] requires 4 molecules of ATP and 2 molecules of GTP to proceed spontaneously. Gluconeogenesis is often associated with [[ketosis]]. Gluconeogenesis is also a target of therapy for [[type 2 diabetes]], such as the [[antidiabetic drug]], [[metformin]], which inhibits glucose formation and stimulates glucose uptake by cells.<ref name = Hundal>{{cite journal |vauthors=Hundal RS, Krssak M, Dufour S, Laurent D, Lebon V, Chandramouli V, Inzucchi SE, Schumann WC, Petersen KF, Landau BR, Shulman GI | title = Mechanism by Which Metformin Reduces Glucose Production in Type 2 Diabetes | journal = Diabetes | volume = 49 | issue = 12 | pages = 2063–69 | year = 2000 | pmid = 11118008 | pmc = 2995498 | doi = 10.2337/diabetes.49.12.2063 }} {{cite web|url= http://diabetes.diabetesjournals.org/cgi/reprint/49/12/2063 |title=Free full text }} {{small|(82 [[Kibibyte|KiB]])}}</ref> In [[ruminant]]s, because dietary carbohydrates tend to be metabolized by [[rumen]] organisms, gluconeogenesis occurs regardless of fasting, low-carbohydrate diets, exercise, etc.<ref name=Beitz2004/>
==Precursors== [[File:Amino acid catabolism revised.png|thumb|300px|Catabolism of [[proteinogenic amino acid]]s. Amino acids are classified according to the abilities of their products to enter gluconeogenesis:<ref>{{cite book|chapter=20. Amino Acid Degradation and Synthesis |first1=Denise R|last1= Ferrier|first2=Pamela C|last2=Champe|first3=Richard A|last3=Harvey |title=Biochemistry (Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews) |publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins |location=[[Hagerstwon, MD]] |pages= |isbn=0-7817-2265-9 |oclc= |doi=|publication-date=1 August 2004}}</ref> {{unordered list | [[Glucogenic amino acid]]s have this ability | [[Ketogenic amino acid]]s do not. These products may still be used for [[ketogenesis]] or [[lipid synthesis]]. | Some amino acids are catabolized into both glucogenic and ketogenic products.}}]] In humans the main gluconeogenic precursors are [[lactic acid|lactate]], [[glycerol]] (which is a part of the [[triacylglycerol]] molecule), [[alanine]] and [[glutamine]]. Altogether, they account for over 90% of the overall gluconeogenesis.<ref name="pmid11213896">{{cite journal |vauthors=Gerich JE, Meyer C, Woerle HJ, Stumvoll M | title = Renal gluconeogenesis: Its importance in human glucose homeostasis | journal = [[Diabetes Care]] | volume = 24 | issue = 2 | pages = 382–91 | year = 2001 | url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hans-Juergen_Woerle/publication/12117257_Renal_Gluconeogenesis_Its_importance_in_human_glucose_homeostasis/links/55fff2ba08aec948c4f9c79f.pdf | pmid = 11213896 | doi=10.2337/diacare.24.2.382}}</ref> Other [[glucogenic amino acid]]s as well as all [[citric acid cycle]] intermediates, the latter through conversion to [[oxaloacetate]], can also function as substrates for gluconeogenesis.<ref name = Garrett/> In [[ruminant]]s, propionate is the principal gluconeogenic substrate.<ref name=Beitz2004>Beitz, D. C. 2004. Carbohydrate metabolism. In: Reese, W. O. Dukes' physiology of domestic animals. 12th ed. Cornell Univ. Press. pp. 501–15.</ref><ref>Van Soest, P. J. 1994. Nutritional ecology of the ruminant. 2nd Ed. Cornell Univ. Press. 476 pp.</ref> In nonruminants, including human beings, propionate arises from the β-oxidation of odd-chain and branched-chain fatty acids is a (relatively minor) substrate for gluconeogenesis.<ref>Rodwell V.W., Bender D.A., Botham K.M., Kennelly P.J., Weil P.A., Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, 2018, McGraw-Hill Publishing Company</ref><ref>John Baynes, Marek Dominiczak, Medical Biochemistry (4th Edition, 2014, Elsevier)</ref> Generally, consumption of gluconeogenic substrates in food does not result in increased gluconeogenesis.<ref name="pmid18561209" />.
Lactate is transported back to the liver where it is converted into [[pyruvate]] by the [[Cori cycle]] using the enzyme [[lactate dehydrogenase]]. Pyruvate, the first designated substrate of the gluconeogenic pathway, can then be used to generate glucose.<ref name = Garrett>{{cite book |title=Principles of Biochemistry with a Human Focus |last=Garrett |first=Reginald H. |author2=Charles M. Grisham |year=2002 |publisher=Brooks/Cole, Thomson Learning |location=USA |isbn=0-03-097369-4 |pages=578, 585 }}</ref> [[Transamination]] or [[deamination]] of amino acids facilitates entering of their carbon skeleton into the cycle directly (as pyruvate or oxaloacetate), or indirectly via the citric acid cycle. The contribution of Cori cycle lactate to overall glucose production increases with [[fasting]] duration.<ref name="pmid9725823">{{cite journal | vauthors=Katz J, Tayek JA | title=Gluconeogenesis and the Cori cycle in 12-, 20-, and 40-h-fasted humans | journal= [[American Journal of Physiology]] | volume=275 | issue=3 Pt 1 | pages=E537–42 | year=1998 | url=http://ajpendo.physiology.org/content/275/3/E537.long | pmid = 9725823 }}</ref> Specifically, after 12, 20, and 40 hours of fasting by human volunteers, the contribution of Cori cycle lactate to gluconeogenesis was 41%, 71%, and 92%, respectively.<ref name="pmid9725823" />
Whether even-chain [[fatty acid]]s can be converted into glucose in animals has been a longstanding question in biochemistry.<ref name = Figueiredo>{{cite journal |vauthors=de Figueiredo LF, Schuster S, Kaleta C, Fell DA | title = Can sugars be produced from fatty acids? A test case for pathway analysis tools | journal = Bioinformatics | volume = 25 | issue = 1 | pages = 152–58 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19117076 | doi = 10.1093/bioinformatics/btn621 }}</ref> It is known that [[odd-chain fatty acid]]s can be oxidized to yield [[propionyl-CoA]], a precursor for [[succinyl-CoA]], which can be converted to pyruvate and enter into gluconeogenesis. In plants, specifically seedlings, the [[glyoxylate cycle]] can be used to convert fatty acids ([[acetate]]) into the primary carbon source of the organism. The glyoxylate cycle produces four-carbon dicarboxylic acids that can enter gluconeogenesis.<ref name = Garrett/>
In 1995, researchers identified the glyoxylate cycle in [[nematode]]s.<ref name = Liu>{{cite journal |vauthors=Liu F, Thatcher JD, Barral JM, Epstein HF | title = Bifunctional glyoxylate cycle protein of ''Caenorhabditis elegans'': a developmentally regulated protein of intestine and muscle | journal = Developmental Biology | volume = 169 | issue = 2 | pages = 399–414 | year = 1995 | pmid = 7781887 | doi = 10.1006/dbio.1995.1156 }}</ref> In addition, the glyoxylate enzymes [[malate synthase]] and [[isocitrate lyase]] have been found in animal tissues.<ref name = Kondrashov>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kondrashov FA, Koonin EV, Morgunov IG, Finogenova TV, Kondrashova MN | title = Evolution of glyoxylate cycle enzymes in Metazoa: evidence of multiple horizontal transfer events and pseudogene formation | journal = Biology Direct | volume = 1 | page = 31 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17059607 | pmc = 1630690 | doi = 10.1186/1745-6150-1-31 }}</ref> Genes coding for malate synthase have been identified in other [[metazoan]]s including [[arthropod]]s, [[echinoderm]]s, and even some [[vertebrate]]s. Mammals found to possess these genes include [[monotreme]]s ([[platypus]]) and [[marsupial]]s ([[opossum]]) but not [[placental mammal]]s. Genes for isocitrate lyase are found only in nematodes, in which, it is apparent, they originated in [[horizontal gene transfer]] from bacteria.
The existence of glyoxylate cycles in humans has not been established, and it is widely held that fatty acids cannot be converted to glucose in humans directly. However, [[carbon-14]] has been shown to end up in glucose when it is supplied in fatty acids.<ref name = Weinman>{{cite journal |vauthors=Weinman EO, Strisower EH, Chaikoff IL | title = Conversion of fatty acids to carbohydrate: application of isotopes to this problem and role of the Krebs cycle as a synthetic pathway | journal = Physiol. Rev. | volume = 37 | issue = 2 | pages = 252–72 | year = 1957 | pmid = 13441426 | doi = 10.1152/physrev.1957.37.2.252 }}</ref> Despite these findings, it is considered unlikely that the 2-carbon [[acetyl-CoA]] derived from the oxidation of fatty acids would produce a net yield of glucose via the [[citric acid cycle]] – however, acetyl-CoA can be converted into pyruvate and lactate through the [[ketogenesis|ketogenic pathway]].<ref name = Figueiredo/><ref name=Glew2010>{{cite journal | author = Glew RH | title = You can get there from here: acetone, anionic ketones and even-carbon fatty acids can provide substrates for gluconeogenesis | journal = Niger J Physiol Sci | volume = 25 | issue = 1 | pages = 2–4 | year = 2010 | pmid = 22314896 | doi = }}</ref> Put simply, acetic acid (in the form of acetyl-CoA) is used to partially produce glucose; acetyl groups can only form part of the glucose molecules (not the 5th carbon atom) and require extra substrates (such as pyruvate) in order to form the rest of the glucose molecule. But a roundabout pathway ''does'' lead from acetyl-coA to pyruvate, via [[acetoacetate]], [[acetone]], [[hydroxyacetone]] (acetol) and then either [[propylene glycol]] or [[methylglyoxal]].<ref name="Glew2010"/><ref>{{cite journal | author = Miller ON, Bazzano G | title = Propanediol metabolism and its relation to lactic acid metabolism | journal = Ann NY Acad Sci | volume = 119 | issue = 3 | pages = 957–73 | year = 1965 | pmid = 4285478 | doi = 10.1111/j.1749-6632.1965.tb47455.x | bibcode = 1965NYASA.119..957M | last2 = Bazzano }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Ruddick JA | year = 1972 | title = Toxicology, metabolism, and biochemistry of 1,2-propanediol | journal = Toxicol Appl Pharmacol | volume = 21 | pages = 102–11 | doi = 10.1016/0041-008X(72)90032-4}}</ref>
== Location == In mammals, gluconeogenesis has been believed to be restricted to the liver,<ref name="vander96">{{cite book|last=Widmaier|first=Eric|title=Vander's Human Physiology|year=2006|publisher=McGraw Hill|isbn=0-07-282741-6|page=96}}</ref> the kidney,<ref name=vander96 /> the intestine,<ref name = Mithieux>{{cite journal |vauthors=Mithieux G, Rajas F, Gautier-Stein A | title = A novel role for glucose 6-phosphatase in the small intestine in the control of glucose homeostasis. | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 279 | issue = 43 | pages = 44231–38 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15302872 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.R400011200 }}</ref> and muscle,{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}} but recent evidence indicates gluconeogenesis occurring in [[astrocyte]]s of the brain.<ref name="pmid28101056">{{cite journal | vauthors=Yip J, Geng X, Shen J, Ding Y | title=Cerebral Gluconeogenesis and Diseases | journal= [[Frontiers in Pharmacology]] | volume=7 | pages=521 | year=2017 | url=https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fphar.2016.00521/full | doi=10.3389/fphar.2016.00521 | pmc=5209353 | pmid = 28101056 }}</ref> These organs use somewhat different gluconeogenic precursors. The liver preferentially uses lactate, glycerol, and glucogenic amino acids (especially [[alanine]]) while the kidney preferentially uses lactate, [[glutamine]] and glycerol.<ref name=Gerich2010>{{cite journal | author = Gerich JE | title = Role of the kidney in normal glucose homeostasis and in the hyperglycaemia of diabetes mellitus: Therapeutic implications | journal = Diabetic Medicine | volume = 27 | issue = 2 | pages = 136–142 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20546255 | pmc = 4232006| doi = 10.1111/j.1464-5491.2009.02894.x }}</ref><ref name="pmid11213896" /> Lactate from the [[Cori cycle]] is quantitatively the largest source of substrate for gluconeogenesis, especially for the kidney.<ref name="pmid11213896" /> The liver uses both [[glycogenolysis]] and gluconeogenesis to produce glucose, whereas the kidney only uses gluconeogenesis.<ref name="pmid11213896" /> After a meal, the liver shifts to [[Glycogenesis|glycogen synthesis]], whereas the kidney increases gluconeogenesis.<ref name="pmid18561209">{{cite journal | vauthors=Nuttall FQ, Ngo A, Gannon MC | title=Regulation of hepatic glucose production and the role of gluconeogenesis in humans: is the rate of gluconeogenesis constant? | journal= Diabetes/metabolism Research and Reviews | volume=24 | issue=6 | pages=438–58 | year=2008 | url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Mary_Gannon3/publication/5293921_Regulation_of_hepatic_glucose_production_and_the_role_of_gluconeogenesis_in_humans_Is_the_rate_of_gluconeogenesis_constant/links/00b7d53a5e9652ec3a000000.pdf | doi= 10.1002/dmrr.863 | pmid = 18561209 }}</ref> The intestine uses mostly glutamine and glycerol.<ref name = Mithieux />
Propionate is the principal substrate for gluconeogenesis in the ruminant liver, and the ruminant liver may make increased use of gluconeogenic amino acids, e.g. alanine, when glucose demand is increased.<ref>Overton, T. R., J. K. Drackley, C. J. Ottemann-Abbamonte, A. D. Beaulieu, L. S. Emmert and J. H. Clark. 1999. Substrate utilization for hepatic gluconeogenesis is altered by increased glucose demand in ruminants. J. Anim. Sci. 77: 1940–51.</ref> The capacity of liver cells to use lactate for gluconeogenesis declines from the preruminant stage to the ruminant stage in calves and lambs.<ref>Donkin, S. S. and L. E. Armentano. 1995. Insulin and glucagon regulation of gluconeogenesis in preruminating and ruminating bovine. J. Anim. Sci. 73: 546–51.</ref> In sheep kidney tissue, very high rates of gluconeogenesis from propionate have been observed.<ref name="pmid7601789">{{cite journal |vauthors=Donkin SS, Armentano LE | title = Insulin and glucagon regulation of gluconeogenesis in preruminating and ruminating bovine | journal = J. Anim. Sci. | volume = 73 | issue = 2 | pages = 546–51 | year = 1995 | pmid = 7601789 | doi = }}</ref>
In all species, the formation of [[oxaloacetate]] from [[pyruvate]] and TCA cycle intermediates is restricted to the mitochondrion, and the enzymes that convert [[Phosphoenolpyruvic acid]] (PEP) to glucose-6-phosphate are found in the cytosol.<ref name="Voet556" >{{cite book |title= Fundamentals of Biochemistry |last= Voet |first= Donald |author2=Judith Voet |author3=Charlotte Pratt |year= 2008 |publisher= John Wiley & Sons Inc |isbn=978-0-470-12930-2 |page=556}}</ref> The location of the enzyme that links these two parts of gluconeogenesis by converting [[oxaloacetate]] to PEP – [[phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase|PEP carboxykinase]] (PEPCK) – is variable by species: it can be found entirely within the [[mitochondria]], entirely within the [[cytosol]], or dispersed evenly between the two, as it is in humans.<ref name="Voet556" /> Transport of PEP across the [[mitochondrial membrane]] is accomplished by dedicated transport proteins; however no such proteins exist for [[oxaloacetate]].<ref name="Voet556" /> Therefore, in species that lack intra-mitochondrial PEPCK, [[oxaloacetate]] must be converted into [[malate]] or [[aspartate]], exported from the [[mitochondrion]], and converted back into [[oxaloacetate]] in order to allow gluconeogenesis to continue.<ref name="Voet556" /> [[File:Gluconeogenesis pathway.png|thumb|300px|Gluconeogenesis pathway with key molecules and enzymes. Many steps are the opposite of those found in the [[glycolysis]].]]
==Pathway== Gluconeogenesis is a pathway consisting of a series of eleven enzyme-catalyzed reactions. The pathway will begin in either the liver or kidney, in the mitochondria or cytoplasm of those cells, this being dependent on the substrate being used. Many of the reactions are the reverse of steps found in [[glycolysis]]. * Gluconeogenesis begins in the mitochondria with the formation of oxaloacetate by the carboxylation of pyruvate. This reaction also requires one molecule of [[adenosine triphosphate|ATP]], and is catalyzed by [[pyruvate carboxylase]]. This enzyme is stimulated by high levels of [[acetyl-CoA]] (produced in [[β-oxidation]] in the liver) and inhibited by high levels of ADP and glucose. * Oxaloacetate is reduced to [[malate]] using [[Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide|NADH]], a step required for its transportation out of the mitochondria. * Malate is oxidized to oxaloacetate using NAD<sup>+</sup> in the cytosol, where the remaining steps of gluconeogenesis take place. * Oxaloacetate is decarboxylated and then phosphorylated to form [[phosphoenolpyruvate]] using the enzyme [[phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase|PEPCK]]. A molecule of [[guanosine triphosphate|GTP]] is hydrolyzed to [[guanosine diphosphate|GDP]] during this reaction. * The next steps in the reaction are the same as reversed [[glycolysis]]. However, [[fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase]] converts [[fructose 1,6-bisphosphate]] to [[fructose 6-phosphate]], using one water molecule and releasing one phosphate (in glycolysis, [[phosphofructokinase 1]] converts F6P and [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] to F1,6BP and [[Adenosine diphosphate|ADP]]). This is also the rate-limiting step of gluconeogenesis. * [[Glucose-6-phosphate]] is formed from [[fructose 6-phosphate]] by [[phosphoglucoisomerase]] (the reverse of step 2 in glycolysis). Glucose-6-phosphate can be used in other metabolic pathways or dephosphorylated to free glucose. Whereas free glucose can easily diffuse in and out of the cell, the phosphorylated form (glucose-6-phosphate) is locked in the cell, a mechanism by which intracellular glucose levels are controlled by cells. * The final reaction of gluconeogenesis, the formation of glucose, occurs in the [[lumen (anatomy)|lumen]] of the [[endoplasmic reticulum]], where glucose-6-phosphate is hydrolyzed by [[glucose-6-phosphatase]] to produce glucose and release an inorganic phosphate. Like two steps prior, this step is not a simple reversal of glycolysis, in which [[hexokinase]] catalyzes the conversion of glucose and ATP into G6P and ADP. Glucose is shuttled into the cytoplasm by [[glucose transporter]]s located in the endoplasmic reticulum's membrane. {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" width="100%" style="text-align:left" ! Metabolism of common [[monosaccharide]]s, including [[glycolysis]], gluconeogenesis, [[glycogenesis]] and [[glycogenolysis]] |- |[[File:Metabolism of common monosaccharides, and related reactions.png|none|1000px]] |}
==Regulation== While most steps in gluconeogenesis are the reverse of those found in [[glycolysis]], three regulated and strongly endergonic reactions are replaced with more kinetically favorable reactions. [[Hexokinase]]/[[glucokinase]], [[phosphofructokinase]], and [[pyruvate kinase]] enzymes of glycolysis are replaced with [[glucose-6-phosphatase]], [[fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase]], and [[PEP carboxykinase]]/pyruvate carboxylase. These enzymes are typically regulated by similar molecules, but with opposite results. For example, [[acetyl CoA]] and [[citrate]] activate gluconeogenesis enzymes (pyruvate carboxylase and fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase, respectively), while at the same time inhibiting the glycolytic enzyme [[pyruvate kinase]]. This system of reciprocal control allow glycolysis and gluconeogenesis to inhibit each other and prevents a [[futile cycle]] of synthesizing glucose to only break it down.
The majority of the [[enzymes]] responsible for gluconeogenesis are found in the [[cytosol]]; the exceptions are mitochondrial [[pyruvate carboxylase]] and, in animals, [[phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase]]. The latter exists as an isozyme located in both the [[mitochondrion]] and the [[cytosol]].<ref name="pmid15917397">{{cite journal |vauthors=Chakravarty K, Cassuto H, Reshef L, Hanson RW | title = Factors that control the tissue-specific transcription of the gene for phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase-C | journal = Crit. Rev. Biochem. Mol. Biol. | volume = 40 | issue = 3 | pages = 129–54 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15917397 | doi = 10.1080/10409230590935479 }}</ref> The rate of gluconeogenesis is ultimately controlled by the action of a key enzyme, [[fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase]], which is also regulated through signal transduction by [[Cyclic adenosine monophosphate|cAMP]] and its phosphorylation.
Global control of gluconeogenesis is mediated by [[glucagon]] (''released when blood glucose is low''); it triggers phosphorylation of enzymes and regulatory proteins by [[Protein kinase A|Protein Kinase A]] (a cyclic AMP regulated kinase) resulting in inhibition of glycolysis and stimulation of gluconeogenesis. [[Insulin]] counteracts glucagon by inhibiting gluconeogenesis. Type 2 diabetes is marked by excess glucagon and [[insulin resistance]] from the body.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2009-05-15|title=Metformin and Insulin Suppress Hepatic Gluconeogenesis through Phosphorylation of CREB Binding Protein|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867409002761|journal=Cell|language=en|volume=137|issue=4|pages=635–646|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2009.03.016|issn=0092-8674}}</ref> Insulin can no longer inhibit the gene expression of enzymes such as PEPCK which leads to increased levels of hyperglycemia in the body.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hatting|first=Maximilian|last2=Tavares|first2=Clint D.J.|last3=Sharabi|first3=Kfir|last4=Rines|first4=Amy K.|last5=Puigserver|first5=Pere|date=2017-09-03|title=Insulin regulation of gluconeogenesis|url=https://rdcu.be/Oyp0|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=1411|issue=1|pages=21–35|doi=10.1111/nyas.13435|issn=0077-8923}}</ref> The anti-diabetic drug [[metformin]] reduces blood glucose primarily through inhibition of gluconeogenesis, overcoming the failure of insulin to inhibit glucogeneogenesis due to insulin resistance.<ref name="pmid29115403">{{cite journal | vauthors=Wang Y, Tang H, Ji X, Zhang Y, Xu W, Yang X, Deng R, Liu Y, Li F, Wang X, Zhou L | title=Expression profile analysis of long non-coding RNAs involved in the metformin-inhibited gluconeogenesis of primary mouse hepatocytes | journal= [[International Journal of Molecular Medicine]] | volume=41 | issue=1 | pages=302–310 | year=2018 | url=https://www.spandidos-publications.com/ijmm/41/1/302 | doi=10.3892/ijmm.2017.3243 | PMC=5746302 | PMID = 29115403 }}</ref>
Studies have shown that the absence of hepatic glucose production has no major effect on the control of fasting plasma glucose concentration. Compensatory induction of gluconeogenesis occurs in the kidneys and intestine, driven by [[glucagon]], [[glucocorticoids]], and acidosis.<ref name = Mutel>{{cite journal |vauthors=Mutel E, Gautier-Stein A, Abdul-Wahed A, Amigó-Correig M, Zitoun C, Stefanutti A, Houberdon I, Tourette JA, Mithieux G, Rajas F | title = Control of blood glucose in the absence of hepatic glucose production during prolonged fasting in mice: induction of renal and intestinal gluconeogenesis by glucagon | journal = Diabetes | volume = 60 | issue = 12 | pages = 3121–31 | year = 2011 | pmid = 22013018 | pmc = 3219939 | doi = 10.2337/db11-0571 }}</ref>

revision.text:
An '''hexathlon''' is a [[Combined track and field events|combined event]] competition consisting of six different sports or contests.
==Track and field== An hexathlon in [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]] is an event which consists of six [[track and field]] events. The word "hexathlon" derives from the Greek words hexa, the number 6, and athlos, meaning contest. A hexathlon is not often organized, mostly at youth levels. It was on the program of the [[Central American and Caribbean Age Group Championships in Athletics]] until 2007, [[South American Youth Championships in Athletics]] until 1998 and the [[South American Junior Championships in Athletics]] until 1974.
The word hexathlon is also used for other forms of combined contests, like bridge, gaming, workouts, etc..
== References == *[http://www.brianmac.co.uk/hexathlon/index.htm Brian Mac Sports Coach]
[[Category:Combined track and field events]] [[Category:Multisports]]
The hexathlon consists of 75m hurdles, long jump, javelin, high jump, shot put and the 800m.
